Huguet got his third part, and the remaining 2/3rds is shared between Bartholomayretus and Dulcieta. Dulcieta is due her dowry and augmentum, namely, 100 florins. They agreed on an arbitration to be settled by Peire Athos, amicus, and Antoni Torcai, brother of Dulciete, and on Bartholomayretus side magister Laurens Aycart, notary, and magister Jaufres Aycart, cooper, his cousins.

Peyret has therefore asked his father for “sufragium vite sue.” Therefore, moved by paternal affection, Bernat assigns to Peyret the things below.

Unlike post-mortem inventories from the period, even those of relatively middling artisans, this inventory reveals a distinct absence of fine goods, clothing, and even foodstuffs. The inventory was conducted by the notary of the court, accompanied by the sub-viguier and the vice-treasurer of the city

name: Act 2921, 3B 145, fol./p. 114r-118r
comments: fol. 114v Discussio bonorum Mosse Creguti, judei. Tuesday, 1405, 24 November. Arfila, the widow of Mosse Creguti, appears in court. She says that the late Mosse died intestate not long ago leaving Salvetus and Astruguetus his sons, also her sons. They are older than 18 years. Sensing that the estate was burdened with debts, they abandoned it, totally abstaining and repudiating. She also said that no one was found who might have wished to defend the bona of Mosse. She also said that at the time of their marriage, Saluomis de Montepessullano, Arfila’s father, gave Mosse in dowry for Arfila 40 florins in coins and in clothing, arnesia, and jocalia. Her husband acknowledged receiving it and promised to restore it, obligating all his bona. /115r/ This is noted by two public instruments written and signed iuxta lectionem eorum manu et signo magistri Rostagni Colomberii notarii condam of this city in the year 1359, 7 July. She wants to get her dowry back. Therefore she asks curator for the undefended goods be named, i.e. magister Abraham de Mayranicis, physician, a citizen and resident of Marseille. Magister Abraam, curator for Arfila, appears and asks for an inventory.

name: Act 2922, 3B 145, fol./p. 120r-125v
comments: Guilhem died intestate, leaving two small children, namely Messenona aged 6 and Antonetus age 3 years. Margarita wants a tutor and doesn’t want to be tutrix herself. She wants as tutor Michael Bertrandi, son of the late Guilhem, brother of the children. He is present, and says that he cannot be tutor for the children since he is engaged in litigation against the children by reason of Michael’s mother’s dowry and also his own wife’s dowry. /120v/ The judge had a colloquium with other friends of the children, asking whether Margarita’s father, the avus of the children, would be okay. They unanimously responded ipsum avum nichil possidere in bonis nec esse sufficienter seu ydoneum ad regimen et gubernationem huiusmodi tutele. So the judge asked noble A. de Rocaforti to be tutor.

name: Act 2923, 3B 38, fol./p. 145v-
comments: Bertomieu Martin (junior) has a wife named Francisca; Raolin Martini has a wife named Nicolaua. The brothers are seeking to recuperate their mother Sanxia’s dowry from the estate of their father. Francisca is seeking her dowry of 300l. Nicolaua is seeking her dowry of 600l. Sanxia was the universal heir of her father, Raymon Raolin. When Sanxia died fourteen years ago, she named Bertomieu and Raolin as her heirs but gave her husband usufruct of her estate for his life. Their father Bertomieu (senior) has remarried to a woman named Nicolaua. He is antiquus et senio. They want to extract their inheritance from his estate so that it doesn't go to his children by his wife Nicolaua.

name: Act 2924, 3B 41, fol./p. 12v-15v
comments: Raymundus is identified as a seaman (marinarius) from the Barcelona. He and his wife and mother-in-law have gone bankrupt and have fled the city (they are described as fugitives). The case includes all the claims of the creditors (not included here). The court conducted an inventory of the goods they left behind. Some of the goods belong generically to Raymundus; others are identified specifically as in the possession of Secilia and Guillelma. See 1340-02 for inventory of Guillelma

name: Act 2925, 3B 41, fol./p. 16r-17r
comments: See 1340-01. Bona reperta infra domum dicte Guillelme fugitive sunt hee que quidem bona scripta et annotata fuere [sic] mandato domini judicis supradicti ad instancia /Folio 16r/ creditorum superius nominatorum et ad instanciam Imberti de Alamanono asserentis se in bonis infrascriptis ius habere

name: Act 2926, 3B 50, fol./p. 7r-
comments: His children are Enricus and Johan. His estate is onerata et potissime propter dotem eorum matris pro qua restituenda ipsa hereditas est eis obligata et propter alia bona et quantitates pecuniarum diversis q. et quas dictus condam eorum pater habuit de bonis adventiciis dictorum filiorum volentes. Someone named Johan Cayrellerii is involedOnly houses and bastitas; no goods

name: Act 2927, 3B 57, fol./p. 89v-90v
comments: Pons Gassin, tutor for his niece Sibileta, had killed Alasacia Morgona. He was sentenced to loss of all his goods. Her inheritance was caught up in his goods. Large estate, including 5 ag. lands, 2 hospicia in bourgs in c. Pilarum, half of the legais of Hugueta mother of Sileta by Bert. Gassini her husband

name: Act 2928, 3B 61, fol./p. 167r-168r
comments: Dispute over the bona of J. Bermundi+ ...que omnia bona mobilia habet penes se Hugo Berengarii notarii

name: Act 2929, 3B 62, fol./p. 15r-17v
comments: 7 November, something has arisen before the judge Petrus Viri. The document speaks of rights held by the Pisans and other people in the goods of Bartholomeus Egidii. A familiar of the sub-vicar is told to go to the cellar of Bartholomeus located near St. Martin. There is a cask full of wine with doganibus in the cellar. He should arrest and take it into the hands of the court and seal it wih the seal of the court, and order Bartholomeus … not to transport or alienate the cask.

name: Act 2931, 5G 775, fol./p. 1r-14v
comments: Guilhem Valencie instituted Biatrix as his universal life heir

name: Act 2932, 5G 775, fol./p. 181r-198r
comments: Dulcia instituted as her universal heirs Margarita de Favacio and Laurencia de Monteolivo, her daughters, nuns of Saint-Sauveur. The act was done on 19 April. The nuns would like to take up the inheritance with benefit of inventory, lest creditors have claims beyond the powers of the estate.  The file includes the inventory (fol. 184r ff.). Dulcia is the daughter of the late Giraut Manentis and the late domine Laurencie. “...melius est sub metu mortis vivere in hoc mundo et de bonis suis provide ordinare ac ordinata relinquere quam sub spe vivendi diutius ad mortem subit pervenire.” [fol. 184v] They also had a daughter Catharine. She wants to be carried there in una litheria cum una stueria. [fol. 185v] She leaves to her son-in-law, Blaquerie de Monteolivo (sic), a domum seu bastitam cum toto suo affair terrarum sitam in territoria castre Sancti Masselli loco dicto Val Juhet. She leaves to Laurencia, daughter and coheir, omnia bona mea mobilia seu omnes et quascumque res meas mobiles sistentes et sistentia in domo mee habitationis seu que repererientur in domo ipsa tempore mortis mee. She then asks that Laurencia, her daughter with Blaquerie, and Margarita de Favassio, nun, her daughter with Aycart de Favas, her first husband, sell within one year after her death all her immovable or stable goods (inmobilia seu stabilia), census, et servitia, and also all her movable goods and the names of her debtors and people from whom she holds rights...After a short space of time, the lord official, leaving the curia and personally discussing with me, the notary, and the witnesses named below, to the house of the deceased ... the two nuns... the transfer of the key of the great door... placed them in corporal possession of the goods... opening and closing the great door with the key in true sign of possession... enacted within the said house in hte presence of P. de Serveriis, knight, and others ... all creditors cited if they want to be presence at the confection of the inventory.... notes from all the parish priests included to confirm that the citation was read aloud in the churches: Sedis, St. Laurent, St. Cannat, Acuis, St. Martin. [fol. 189r] Saturday, 18 May, Johan Mounier, proc for the nuns, petit se admitti ad confectionem et publicationem inventarii supradicti, presentibus quinque testibus et tabellione inferius descriptis ydoneis et facultatibus opulentis habentibus plenariam noticiam testatricis et heredum predictarum q. dicit in presencia creditorum legatariorum et fideicomissiorum et aliorum si q. fut pretendentium se ius habere in bonis et hereditate domine Dulciete testatricis predicte si compereant alis in eorum contumacia quam accusat cum citati extiterint legitime et more solito ad hos diem horam et actum? [fol. 190r] A repetition of the notices from the parish priests.  [fol. 191v] Johannes Mounerii, nomine quo supra, volens evitare pena a iure stabilitas heredibus sive gadiatoribus inventarium non facientibus seu conficientibus de bonis et rebus quorum sunt heredes et ut beneficium sibi dicto nomine servetur illesum dicit et proficetur se invenisse in bonis et hereditate dicte quondam domine Dulciete de Monteolivo bona et res que secuntur. Et ideo suum inventarium oncohavit per modum vez infrascriptum, primo venerabili signo sancte + manu sua propria cum calamo et tincta factos in presente inventario. In primis dixit et manifestavit se invenisse in bonis et hereditate predictis bona et res que sequntur.

name: Act 2933, 1-II 44, fol./p. 62r-63v
comments: In the presence of the judge Guilhem de Montoliu, the two women ask for an Inventory of the goods for the sake of avoiding penas et malas suspiciones. They ask in each of their names (per quamlibet earumdem nominibus)

name: Act 2934, 1-II 44, fol./p. 58v-59v
comments: Dixit se invenisse in bonis et de bonis dictorum condam coniugum et hereditate dicti pupilli prout datus est ei intelligi...

name: Act 2935, 1-II 44, fol./p. 66r-67v
comments: In primis dixit dicta Jacmeta Francha seu Griffena se invenisse in bonis et de bonis dicti condam Nycolaueti Franchi prout datus est ei intelligi

name: Act 2937, 1-II 44, fol./p. 43r-45r
comments: In primis dixit se invenisse bona infrascripta ... videlicet

name: Act 2938, 1-II 44, fol./p. 64r-65v
comments: Her father died in the anno mortalitatis terribilis just past. He wrote a testament, instituted Alaysacia Paul, his wife and mother of Alayseta as his heir. Alayseta and Johanneta, his daughters, were substitute heirs in equal parts. The instrument was made by Jacme Aycart, notary, in 1347/8, 15 March. See 1JA(1348)43 for the testament of Alayseta’s husband, Ugo Porrate. See 1JA(1348)30 for the testament of Bertran Paul. There is some history here (Johanneta, for example, is inpotens.)

name: Act 2939, 1-II 44, fol./p. 70v-71r
comments: Her testament was executed by Petrus Lurdi, notary, in 1350, 1 May. She instituted Peire de Antibolo as her heir. He wishes benefit of inventory.

name: Act 2940, 1-II 61, fol./p. 9v
comments: Simon is a resident of the city. His wife, deceased, is Franque; they reside in a house belonging to Antoni Lurdi in Lansaria. Simon died intestate and left no heirs or relatives closer in kinship than Albertinus Sanchonius, nephew or felezenus of Symon.

name: Act 2941, 3-II 157/2, fol./p. *
comments: From an edition, As of January 2013, not checked thoroughly against original for errors of OCR or transcription. The inventory lists the houses and then the contents of the houses, in that order. I started trying to sort the contents into the appropriate houses but didn’t finish because of ambiguity.

name: Act 2942, FF 1009, fol./p. 49r-50v
comments: She is seeking to recover a dowry of 34l. = 21fl. 2gr. Expenses of 1fl., total of 22fl. 2gr

name: Act 2943, FF 1009, fol./p. 84r-86r
comments: This is not necessarily a complete inventory. Among other things, there are no clothes. The total sum assigned here is 176fl. 5gr., i.e. almost exactly the amount assigned. Possibly a number of items were left out of the reckoning

name: Act 2945, FF 1009, fol./p. 1r-5r
comments: Johaneta is seeking to recover a dowry of 100 florins and an additional sum of 4 florins, plus expenses. Room by room inventory of the house and shop

name: Act 2946, FF 1009, fol./p. 14r-15v
comments: Jacmeta is seek to recover a dowry of 110 florins, from a dowry instrument dated 27 January 1411, plus expenses. Inventory is not obviously carried out room-by-room. No real estate is found. Total value of goods is 69 florins 3 gr. Jacmeta gets 45 fl. and 11 gr.?

name: Act 2947, FF 1009, fol./p. 27r-28r
comments: She is seeking a dowry of 70l. [43fl. 9gr.] with expenses of 3l. The house and pasture are worth 15fl., and the goods 15fl. 1¾ gr. Thus, she is short 13fl. 7¼gr.

name: Act 2948, FF 1009, fol./p. 45r-48v
comments: She is seeking to recover a dowry of 160l. Total with expenses is 113fl. 11gr. 1q. Total value of estate is the same (!). Land is worth 81fl.; goods worth 32fl. 11gr. 1q. /fol. 46r = 2341.jpg

name: Act 2949, FF 1009, fol./p. 65r-66v
comments: Case 3. Alaeta Audeberta, the mother, was a creditor to Lazarus the cooper, for 10 fl. At the same time, Jacmeta, the daughter, was in debt to him for 5fl. and a bit. Aleata died, passing the credit on to the daughter and thereby extinguishing all of her debt and then some.  Case 4. She is recovering usque quantitatem unius tacee argenti ponderis unius marche

name: Act 2950, FF 1009, fol./p. 69r-70v et al.
comments: She is seeking to recover a dowry of 100fl. and expenses of 3fl. 4gr. The goods only are worth 28fl. 2½gr

name: Act 2951, FF 1009, fol./p. 77r-79v
comments: no values

name: Act 2952, FF 1009, fol./p. 31r-33v
comments: She is seeking to recover a dowry of 300l. She has already been assigned 40l. of aliments. 8l. expenses. She and her husband together owed 100fl. to Gabriel Vassal, which she paid off, and she adds that sum. The total is 508 pounds, and with expenses (including funeral expenses) the sum comes to 586l. 16s. The goods are worth 536l. 8s. The immovable wealth is worth 122l. The movable bona are therefore worth 414l. 8s.

name: Act 2953, FF 1009, fol./p. 35r-38v
comments: 1000fl. dowry; 300 florins; 200 florins; 7 1/2 florins; 15fl. for funeral expenses; total is 1522fl. 6gr. She ended up receiving 1029fl. 11 gr. 1 quartum, after subtracting 40fl. 7gr. and 2 quarters for the anniversary masses

name: Act 2954, FF 1009, fol./p. 39r-40v
comments: She is seeking to recover a dowry of 300fl.; instrument 28 July 1392. Expenses are 303fl. The single house is worth 62fl. 6gr. She is still owed 181fl. 5gr. 3q. Apparently she received 121 fl. 6gr. and 1q. The goods are therefore worth 59fl. and 1q

name: Act 2955, FF 1009, fol./p. 41r-44r
comments: She is seeking to recover a dowry of 100l. = 62.5fl. She paid expenses and medicines of 20fl. 9gr. and 2q. An addition debt to Jacme of 14fl. 3gr. Total debt claimed is 98fl. 3gr. 2q. Total amount is 106fl. 5gr. 3q. The estate is valued at 109fl. 11gr. Boat and house together worth 80fl. so only 29fl. 11gr. in goods.
